1.segment: Introduction As COVID-19 vaccinations became available and were proven effective in preventing serious infection , uptake amongst individuals varied .

3.segment: hesitancy and explanatory factors amongst people with serious and/or chronic health conditions ,

4.segment: including the impact of underlying disease on attitudes to vaccination .

7.segment: Participants 4683 patients ( 3560 cancer , 842 diabetes and 281 multiple sclerosis ) receiving care at the health services participated in the 42-item survey ,

9.segment: Main outcome measures Sociodemographic and disease-related characteristics ,

10.segment: COVID-19 vaccine uptake , and the scores of three validated scales which measured vaccine hesitancy and vaccine-related beliefs generally and specific to the participants ' disease ,

11.segment: including the Oxford COVID-19 Vaccine Hesitancy Scale ,

12.segment: the Oxford COVID-19 Vaccine Confidence and Complacency Scale and the Disease Influenced Vaccine Acceptance Scale .

13.segment: Multivariable logistic regression was used to determine the associations between scale scores and vaccine uptake .

14.segment: Results Of all participants , 81.5 % reported having at least one COVID-19 vaccine .

15.segment: Unvaccinated status was associated with younger age ,

16.segment: female sex , lower education and income ,

18.segment: and residence in regional areas ( all p < 0.05 ) .

19.segment: Unvaccinated participants were more likely to report greater vaccine hesitancy and more negative perceptions toward vaccines ( all p < 0.05 ) .

20.segment: Disease-related vaccine concerns were associated with unvaccinated status and hesitancy ,

21.segment: including greater complacency about COVID-19 infection ,

22.segment: and concerns relating to vaccine efficacy and impact on their disease and/or treatment ( all p < 0.05 ) .

23.segment: Conclusions Disease-specific concerns impact COVID-19 vaccine-related behaviours and beliefs in people with serious and/or chronic health conditions .

24.segment: This highlights the need to develop targeted strategies and education about COVID-19 vaccination to support medically vulnerable populations and health professionals .
